title: Heidi's Portfolio
text:
About Me
Hi, I’m Heidi!
I am BSc. student at UBC, graduating this May! I have a major in statistics and a minor in data science.
My interests involve consulting, data visualization, actuarial science, and data engineering.
Please take a look through my website to learn more!

title: Lakehouse Architecture with Databricks
text:
My Certifications


Lakehouse Architecture with Databricks

Course ID: E-VP9791
Completed 5/5/2025
Certificate of Completion:




Get Started With Lakehouse Architecture




Additional Information



See the course here: https://www.databricks.com/learn/training/get-started-lakehouse-architecture#data-video
Learning Objectives:


Describe the available compute options for workloads performed on the databricks data intelligence platform


List the products and features databricks offers for different data-centric needs within the databricks platform


Navigate the databricks workspace UI


Develop an agreed upon set of terminology and concepts for discussing Lakehouse Architecture


Define the framework of a modern data and AI platform


Explain the range of functions, capabilities, and use cases for data lakehouses within enterprise businesses.


Describe the rules that make up the guiding philosophy behind a data lakehouse architecture


Use the guiding princples of the lakehouse architecture to verify that your organizations data strategy aligns with the vision of the Databricks Data Intelligence Platform.


Identify the componenets of a lakehouse architecture by reviewing available reference architecture for your given cloud implementation.


Differentiate between the different roles and responsibilities of Databricks Data Intelligence platform features and products and those provided by the cloud service provider in a lakehouse architecture.


Describe the well-architected framework adopted by the three largest cloud service providers.


Explain how Databricks has adapted and built upon the cloud well-architected framework for the well-architected lakehouse framework.


List the seven pillars of the well-architected lakehouse framework.




Research Ethics

Completed 12/1/2025
Certificate of Completion:




Ethical Conduct for Research Involving Humans




Additional Courses (tied with Certifications)

Get started with Azure DevOps
Get started with Microsoft Fabric
Implement a data engineering solution with Azure Databricks
Implement Generative AI engineering with Azure Databricks

title: Student Statistical Consultant (Capstone Project)
text:
My Projects



Student Statistical Consultant (Capstone Project)

With guidance from Dr. Rodolfo Lourenzutti, I worked for a client analyzing changes in glaucoma eye surgery in an apprentice type of job.
Real client work, regular meetings with the professor presenting work, poster board and oral presentations
Produced reports, code, and worked directly for the client using the R programming language and GitHub
Learned about complications with study design, model selection, and effective statistical communication
See our poster we presented in a poster board session:




STAT 450 Poster Board





The Daily Grind (CMD-F Hackathon)

A 24 hour Computer Science Hackathon on the weekend of March 8-9th, 2025
Winners of the “Social Track” for our coffee-chat conversation starter using AI
Won 3rd place overall, with 50+ projects and 200+ participants
Presented work to 7 judges individually, and in the final round presented in front of the entire Hackathon community (over 250+ people).
For further details, see our devpost: https://devpost.com/software/the-daily-grind




Reproducible and Trustworthy Workflows: DSCI 310 Group Project

Create a statistical analysis that incorporates these main ideas:

Data Pipelines
Make and Makefiles
Dockerfiles
Creating an R Package

See our analysis repository: https://github.com/DSCI-310-2025/dsci-310-group-7-data-dudes
And our package repository: https://github.com/DSCI-310-2025/pkg.drugage



Weather Extremes Research

Working at UBC from May to August 2024 under an URSA NSERC scholarship
Working under professors Harry Joe and Natalia Nolde, I found patterns and explanations for climate extremes.
Dealt with Canadian weather data, relating to floods, droughts, and wildfires using Python and R languages.
Completed EDA and used various statistical analyses to gain insight into weather patterns and time series analysis.
Analyzed many research papers, presented work weekly, and assisted both professors with various tasks.
Will be publishing work on a public repository soon!




ASA DataFest

A 48 hour Hackathon in a team of 3
Created a fully reproducible project, with a clear statistical analysis
Created a dashboard, demonstration video, presentation using quarto, and analysis using a Bayesian model
Info about ASA DataFest: https://ww2.amstat.org/education/datafest/
See our repository work here: https://github.com/hlan22/asa_datafest_2025
See our presentation here: https://hlan22.github.io/asa_datafest_2025/#/title-slide




Wordplayr - An R Package

A fully functioning R package with clear instructions on how to install and use
The aim of wordplay is to learn more about your favorite list of words! Learn about metrics such as length, frequent starting letters, and much more with ease!
See the package I made here: https://github.com/hlan22/wordplay




Easy EDA (Personal Project)

R Package in development such that you can “automate” EDA for any given dataset.
Functions will quickly and easily create proper plots based on data types, for any and all columns.
All code will be done with R initially, but will expand to Python too, for interactive visuals.
Link to the Repo

title: All About Websites!
text:
This is my first website, so here I will talk about important info I learn here!

For basic information on Quarto websites I started with: https://quarto.org/docs/websites.

Any special customization that I do, I hope to outline here as a guide to making your own!

Markdown tips

To receive the outline shown on the right-hand side of this page, specify in the YAML header the following: toc: true.



Styling and Rendering

Create a styles.css file (in the same directory as your index.qmd file) to create custom HTML styling.

For example, the way I created the purple box shown at the bottom of this page is done by putting the following in the styles.css file:


.purplebox {
    background-color: #e3dfff; /* Light Purple */
    border: 3px solid #7a5fa3; /* Dark Purple */
    color: #3d236f; /* Text Color */
    padding: 10px;
    border-radius: 8px;
    text-align: center;
    font-weight: bold;
    font-family: sans-serif;
  }

Which you can then execute by putting this in your document:

:::: purplebox
::: center
**NOTICE!**\
Please know that I am still updating this website... I hope to finish it soon :)
:::
::::

You can create a dropdown menu by doing the following HTML code:

<details>
<summary>Dropdown title</summary>
Contents you want inside the dropdown menu
</details> 
Which looks like:


Dropdown title

Contents you want inside the dropdown menu



NOTICE!
Please know that I am still updating this website… I hope to finish it soon :)

details

Computer Science

CPSC 304
CPSC 210
CPSC 110



Math

MATH 101
MATH 100



Business

COMR 398

An organization’s ultimate success depends on how efficiently and effectively it executes its strategic goals. This requires a detailed understanding of the processes used to produce and deliver goods and/or services to customers including:

process analysis
queuing systems
project management
inventory management
supply chain management

Upon successful completion of this course, students will have the managerial tools needed to understand and articulate the impact of an organization’s business processes, and the ability to analyze and continuously improve these business processes.




Other Courses
